question: Your half full container of hummus has passed its best before date by two days, but it looks and smells fine. What do you do?
answerB: You saved $4.00 by finishing the hummus. Fact Food is not inedible or expired after the best before date. The dates set by manufacturers are conservative, and are not government regulated. Tip Regularly check dates on food and incorporate them into your meals while they are still fresh and appetizing.

question: After a busy week of school/work, you have forgotten to eat a serving of leftover salmon and it has developed a mild, but unusual smell. What do you do?
answerA: You got food poisoning, and lost $10.00 when you threw up the salmon. Fact Don’t eat food off in color, smell or taste. Even if money and food are wasted, it is better than falling ill. Tip Regularly check cooked leftovers for quality and label them with dates to keep track of freshness.

question: While making a shopping list, you check the fridge and see how crowded it is. It will eat into your free time to clean, but you can shop afterwards. What will you do?
optionA: Do a quick scan of fridge
answerA: You lost $5.00 because there was cooked chicken hiding in the back. Fact Avoid overcrowding your fridge to improve the circulation of cold air, and to ensure nothing is forgotten in the back. Tip Catch food that’s gone bad or is about to with quality checks. Also find foods nearing their best before date. Doing a deep clean once a week is recommended.
answerB: You found some chicken and saved money, woohoo!
